thread.title: In his final race at Talladega, Jeff Gordon wins pole
thread.title_full: In his final race at Talladega, Jeff Gordon wins pole

title: In his final race at Talladega, Jeff Gordon wins pole
text:
Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest In his final race at Talladega, Jeff Gordon wins pole Jeff Gordon, one day from racing for the final time at Talladega Superspeedway, roared to the pole position Saturday for Sunday’s CampingWorld.com 500. Post to Facebook In his final race at Talladega, Jeff Gordon wins pole Jeff Gordon, one day from racing for the final time at Talladega Superspeedway, roared to the pole position Saturday for Sunday’s CampingWorld.com 500. Check out this story on USATODAY.com: http://usat.ly/1LUQOpu Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 3 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs In his final race at Talladega, Jeff Gordon wins pole Mike Hembree, Special for USA TODAY 6:54 p.m. EDT October 24, 2015 USA TODAY Sports' Brant James on what everybody is talking about, what to watch for, and who will win in the CampingWorld.com 500. USA TODAY Sports Jeff Gordon will start on the pole for his final Sprint Cup race at Talladega Superspeedway. (Photo: Todd Warshaw, Getty Images) 378 CONNECT 82 TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
TALLADEGA, Ala. — Jeff Gordon, one day from racing for the final time at Talladega Superspeedway, roared to the pole position Saturday for Sunday’s CampingWorld.com 500 with a speed of 194.500 miles per hour. 
Gordon, who earned his 81st career Cup Series pole, was the star of an afternoon that featured blistering speeds from all four Hendrick Motorsports cars. Kasey Kahne was second at 193.638, and Hendrick teammates Jimmie Johnson (third) and Dale Earnhardt Jr. (fifth) followed. 
Matt Kenseth was fourth. 
The qualifying runs open the opportunity for the Hendrick drivers to draft as a group at the front early in Sunday’s race. The day is particularly important for Earnhardt Jr., who needs a win to advance to the third round of the Chase for the Sprint Cup. Dale Earnhardt Jr. remembers father's final Cup win 
“We all understand what’s at stake and what our goal and mission is,” Gordon said. “If we can stay together, we better our chances. We know what Junior has to do and what we have to do. We have four excellent race cars and four race teams to work together to make that happen. 
“We can’t control everything out there, but we can get the green and go racing and see how it works out.” 
Gordon, who also won the pole for the Talladega spring race, was easily the fastest of the 12 drivers who advanced to the second round of qualifying Saturday. He expressed confidence that he will have a good shot at winning in his 46th and final trip around NASCAR’s biggest track. 
Five Chasers — Kurt Busch, Carl Edwards, Kyle Busch, Ryan Newman and Martin Truex Jr. — failed to make the second qualifying round. Gluck: Low-risk riding could reap big reward at Talladega 
The qualifying session was delayed by an unusual occurrence on pit road. When Clint Bowyer was given the OK by NASCAR officials to leave pit road for his qualifying run, his car was in reverse and he bumped into Justin Allgaier’s HScott Motorsports Chevrolet, which was parked behind him. 
The contact caused minor damage to the rear of Bowyer’s car but more significant front-end damage to Allgaier’s. Allgaier’s qualifying run was delayed while his crew patched his Chevrolet’s front end. 
Bowyer apologized afterward, saying he didn’t know his car was in reverse. 'Dega: 'Hopefully it all stays on the ground' 
Ironically, Bowyer will be moving to the HScott team next season. 
Truex Jr.’s qualifying speed was disallowed after he dropped below the track’s inside yellow line during his run. He will start 43rd Sunday. 
Jeb Burton and Michael Annett failed to qualify. 
PHOTOS: Chase drivers, rankings and points
